newsitem.title: USA: Atari founder to offer games, music via Internet.
newsitem.headline: Atari founder to offer games, music via Internet.

text.p: The Silicon Valley entrepreneur who founded Atari Corp said on Thursday he believes he has the formula to sell billions of dollars of coin-operated video games and music using the Internet.

Nolan Bushnell, 52, who now provides seed money and serves as a visionary to numerous high tech firms, told reporters in a wood-paneled room of his mansion here that he expects the market to be worth "billions and billions."

Bushnell said he and Aristo International have invested more than $10 million to develop a line of products that can deliver the Internet, fast-action team games and a jukebox with thousands of titles by accessing the Internet.

At a drop of a coin, or the slide of a credit card for big spenders, individuals will be able to call up the latest electronic games, order a hot new compact disk or access their electronic mail using the systems, he said.

Aristo International plans to roll out three machines -- MusicNet Plus, TouchNet and TeamNet -- to the worldwide market in early September. It has gathered some 75 of the 100 or so distributors of pay-per-play vendor machines this week to unveil the machines and generate orders.
